title: MITTERRAND AND KOHL HONOR DEAD OF VERDUN
title_page: MITTERRAND AND KOHL HONOR DEAD OF VERDUN - The New York Times
maintext:
There were no political speeches, a decision that the veterans approved.
''De Gaulle shook the hand of the Germans 20 years ago and it is right that today we just have a simple ceremony of friendship,'' one Frenchman said.
''If we had had ceremonies like this before World War II, we might have avoided it,'' another said.
The ceremonies today were preceded by a joint military exercise by 2,800 French and West German troops in eastern France.
Before visiting the Ossuary and the graves of French soldiers, President Mitterrand and Chancellor Kohl paid tribute to the German dead at Consenvoye, one of the many German cemeteries in the Verdun region. It holds the remains of 8,700 soldiers.
President Mitterrand invited Chancellor Kohl to Verdun last May. The invitation was widely viewed in France as having been improvised to soothe feelings after the West German leader had been left out of the 40th anniversary celebrations of the Allied landings in Normandy in World War II.
There was no time scheduled for political consultations between the two leaders. But they were expected to meet again in Bonn next month.
